ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned so much about the New Testament from this class! I have been a Christian for my entire life, but I knew very little about the historical context of the New Testament. I think of the New Testament, and the Bible as a whole, completely differently having taken this course. It was a bit outside of my wheelhouse, so I also learned how to analyze scripture and think through the lens of the Bible, which was a lot of fun!
I feel like we did a good in depth analysis of a few topics within the New Testament
Youre really pushed to analyze the Bible and its effects on the modern world in relation to the ancient one- its really cool and puts it all in perspective

This course deeply expanded my ability to think critically about what we mean when we refer to "the Bible" in modern discourse. It challenged a number of my preconceived notions about "the Bible" with a breadth of historical context that makes us question the specific ways it can be applicable to modern audiences.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This course was incredible! The readings were curated very thoughtfully (and kindly, such that they were reasonably doable in their entirety) and I felt like I got something out of everything I read. It is such a gift to see Professor Nasrallah explain passages of Greek. I have a much stronger understanding of every verse she analyzed; every week was a new light bulb moment! My only suggestion would be to differentiate the topics of the three papers a bit more; otherwise, I thought this class was fantastic!
Weakness felt a bit all over the place
The readings were all manageable and all very relevant and interesting, so you always felt productive which was great. The discussion was also just really cool

Pretty much all strengths from me. If there is one spot in which we could have improved, I think we could have practiced a bit more academic empathy towards the persons we studied, but I think this isn't something the Prof. has clear control over.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would absolutely recommend this class to a friend who is interested in dissecting the New Testament! However, be forewarned: don't take this class unless you're ready to have your whole Biblical worldview rocked. It's totally worth the experience, and you will have loads of fun along the way.
Absolutely- it provides so much context for what do much of the world is centered on

Yes. This was my favourite course at Yale -- and it's not close. I became friends with all of my classmates, and I think that's a testament (see what I did there?) to how much we all bought into this course. It opened both eyes and doors for me. I would particularly recommend this course to any student interested in the Christian antiquities, but looking for a grounded window into its implications for modern life.
